column4: Hi guys, when booting my system I suddenly get this error about my filesystem: "mountall: Filesystem has errors: /" and I should run fsck manually
Can you boot a liveCD and run fsck from there?
You don't want to fsck "/" from the LiveCD, you want to find what device is your installed system's root partition and fsck that.
Okay, fdisk -l tells me sda1 2 and 5
sda1 is clean, sda2 is zero length and sda5 says something about a "superblock could not be read or does not describe a correct ext2 filesystem"
Can you pastebin the output of "sudo blkid" ?
Just a sec
http://pastebin.com/CKKCQQQm
Ahh, I assume that your root fs is on top of LVM?
Am not sure what that means?
Did you install this system yourself?
Did you use the Desktop installer or the alternate installer?

Ok, when you installed you chose to have your root filesystem on LVM (Logical Volume Management). In short it's sort of a way to have more flexable pseudo partititions that you can resize and move around much more easily.
But to access the LVM "volume" containing your root filesystem you'll need to install lvm and set a few things up.
Sounds weird as this happened after the host system crashed (As I mentioned, the ubuntu is running as a virtual machine)
Is it hard to fix? I have a backup of the VM, but it means I will lose data (Using ubuntu for dev webserver)
Follow this guide, but run "sudo fsck -y /dev/Volgroup/..." instead of mount. http://linuxwave.blogspot.com/2007/11/mounting-lvm-disk-using-ubuntu-livecd.html
